lead_paragraph: As attorney general in a tough-on-crime era, Ms. Reno dared to ask how many innocent people might be in prison — and what DNA evidence could reveal about how they had gotten there.

headline.print_headline: An Attorney General Unafraid of Science That Could Exonerate the Innocent
headline.main: Janet Reno Was Unafraid of Science That Could Exonerate the Innocent

snippet: As attorney general in a tough-on-crime era, Ms. Reno dared to ask how many innocent people might be in prison — and what DNA evidence could reveal about how they had gotten there....
abstract: Jim Dwyer About New York column remembers late former Atty Gen Janet Reno, who embraced DNA testing as tool in criminal justice, even as it revealed that many innocent people were in jail based on faulty evidence; notes research conducted by Reno and Jeremy Travis, former director of National Institute of Justice, is blueprint for modern criminal justice reform.
